tit.e: Doshisha Women's College of Liberal Arts
Doshisha Women's College of Liberal Arts
Doshisha Women's College of Liberal Arts

sen.j: 1949年に、それまでの旧制専門学校を母体に設置されたプロテスタント系の女子大学で、4学部10学科を有する。
sen.e: Doshisha Women's College of Liberal Arts is a Protestant college for women, which includes 4 faculties and 10 departments, and was reorganized in 1949 as a successor of the former Advanced Course of Doshisha Girls' School.
sen.cmt: 旧制専門学校は、以下に出てくる年表を参照し、同志社女子専門学校（The Advanced Course of Doshisha Girls' School）と訳しました。
sen.e: Doshisha Women's College of Liberal Arts is a Protestant college comprising four faculties and ten departments, having been reorganized in 1949 as a successor of the former Advanced Course of Doshisha Girls' School.

Doshisha Women's College of Liberal Arts is a Protestant college comprising four faculties and ten departments, having been reorganized in 1949 as a successor of the former Advanced Course of Doshisha Girls' School.

sen.j: キャンパスは、京都郊外に広大な敷地を持つ京田辺市キャンパスと、京都市の中心部に位置する今出川キャンパスの2ヶ所ある。
sen.e: The college has 2 campuses; Kyotanabe campus, which has a huge land area, located in the suburb of Kyoto and Imadegawa Campus located in the heart of Kyoto City.
The college has two campuses: the Kyotanabe campus, which covers a vast area in suburban Kyoto; and the Imadegawa Campus, which is located in the heart of Kyoto City.
The college has two campuses: the Kyotanabe campus, which covers a vast area in suburban Kyoto; and the Imadegawa Campus, which is located in the heart of Kyoto City.

sen.j: 1942年2月17日制定の『同志社女子大学学則』では、「キリスト教主義」を基本に、「国際主義」、「リベラル・アーツ」を教育理念として定めている。
sen.e: "School regulations of the Doshisha Women's College of Liberal Arts" was set on February 17 1942, saying that it provides an education based on "Christianity", and its educational philosophies are "Internationalism" and "Liberal Arts."

The "School Regulations of the Doshisha Women's College of Liberal Arts" were set forth on February 17 1942, stating that the institution would provide education based on "Christianity" with "internationalism" and "liberal arts" as its educational philosophies.

The "School Regulations of the Doshisha Women's College of Liberal Arts" were set forth on February 17 1942, stating that the institution would provide education based on "Christianity" with "internationalism" and "liberal arts" as its educational philosophies.

sen.j: リベラル・アーツを教育の柱に据えており、大学の英称も「Doshisha Womens College of Liberal Arts」とした。
sen.e: The college sets its goal of educating women in the liberal arts, and named itself "Doshisha Women's College of Liberal Arts" in English.
The goal of the College was to educate women in the liberal arts, and it was given the English name "Doshisha Women's College of Liberal Arts."
The goal of the College was to educate women in the liberal arts, and it was given the English name "Doshisha Women's College of Liberal Arts."

sen.j: 研究分野では、日本古来の文化である和歌の研究に力を入れており、女子大学としては、この分野で最も有名である。
sen.e: The college focuses on especially the study of Waka, one of the Japanese traditional cultures, gaining a reputation for its study among the women's colleges.
The college focuses on the study of Waka, one of the Japanese traditional cultures, and has acquired a reputation for its study among women's colleges.
The college focuses on the study of Waka, one of the Japanese traditional cultures, and has acquired a reputation for its study among women's colleges.

sen.j: 新島襄によって1876年（明治9年）に京都御苑内の元公家屋敷（大正天皇の生母の実家の柳原家）で、当時は同志社教師デーヴィス氏が住んでいた邸内に設立された同志社女子部（後の同志社女学校）を前身とする。
sen.e: Joseph Hardy Neesima opened a school for girls (later called Doshisha Girls' School) that became the predecessor of Doshisha Women's College of Liberal Arts. The school was within the Kyoto Imperial Palace Park, and it was also the residence of the Doshisha's teacher Davis, in which former court noble (the Yanagihara family, from which emperor Taisho's mother came) had lived.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処。
sen.e: Joseph Hardy Neesima opened a school for girls (later called the Doshisha Girls' School), which was ultimately the predecessor of the Doshisha Women's College of Liberal Arts. The school was within the Kyoto Imperial Palace Park, and it was also the residence of the Doshisha's teacher Davis, in which former court nobility (the Yanagihara family, from which emperor Taisho's mother came) had lived.

Joseph Hardy Neesima (Jo NIIJIMA) opened a school for girls in 1876 (later called the Doshisha Girls' School), which was ultimately the predecessor of the Doshisha Women's College of Liberal Arts. The school was within the Kyoto Imperial Palace Park, and it was also the residence of the Doshisha's teacher Davis, in which former court nobility (the Yanagihara family, from which Emperor Taisho's mother came) had lived.

sen.j: 新島は女子教育の重要性を当時より認識しており、これが女子大設立の理由となった（当時の同志社大学は男子学生のみを対象としていた）。
sen.e: Neesima knew the importance of offering an education for women even in those days, which led him to establish a college for women (Doshisha University then was only for boys).
Even in those days Neesima knew the importance of offering education for women, and this led him to establish a college for women. (At the time, Doshisha University was only for males).
Even in those days Neesima knew the importance of offering education for women, and this led him to establish a college for women (at the time, Doshisha University was for men only).

sen.j: 1876年 - 同志社女子塾を設立。
1877年 - 女子塾を母体に同志社分校女紅場を開設。
sen.e: 1877: Doshisha Bunko Nyokoba was reopened as a successor of the Doshisha Girls' Juku.
1877: Doshisha Bunko Nyokoba was reopened as a successor of the Doshisha Girls' Juku.
1877: Doshisha Bunko Nyokoba was reopened as a successor of the Doshisha Girls' Juku.

sen.j: 同年9月に同志社女学校に改称。
sen.e: In September of the same year, it was renamed Doshisha Girls' School.
In September of the same year it was renamed as the Doshisha Girls' School.
In September of the same year it was renamed as the Doshisha Girls' School.

sen.j: 1930年 - 同志社女子専門学校を設立。
sen.e: 1930: The Advanced Course of Doshisha Girls' School was founded.
sen.cmt: 同志社の年表には、1930年に同志社女子専門学校から同志社女子大学に名称変更とあります。http://www.cis.doshisha.ac.jp/kkitao/doshisha/chronology.htm
sen.e: 1930: The Advanced Course of Doshisha Girls' School was founded.
1930: The Advanced Course of Doshisha Girls' School was founded.

sen.j: 1949年 - 女子専門学校を廃止し、同志社女子大学学芸学部（英文学専攻・音楽専攻・食物学専攻）を設立。
sen.e: 1949: The Advanced Course of Doshisha Girls' School was abolished, and Doshisha Women's College of Liberal Arts (Departments of English Literature, Music, and Food Science) was founded.
1949: The Advanced Course of Doshisha Girls' School was abolished, and Doshisha Women's College of Liberal Arts (with the epartments of English Literature, Music and Food Science) was founded.
1949: The Advanced Course of Doshisha Girls' School was abolished, and Doshisha Women's College of Liberal Arts (with the Departments of English Literature, Music and Food Science) was founded.

sen.j: 1967年 - 家政学部家政学科・食物学科設置。
sen.e: 1967: Faculty of Home Economics (Departments of Home Economics and Food Science) was founded.
1967: The Faculty of Home Economics (including the departments of Home Economics and Food Science) was founded.
1967: The Faculty of Home Economics (including the departments of Home Economics and Food Science) was founded.

sen.j: 1986年 - 田辺キャンパス（現・京田辺キャンパス）を開設。
sen.e: 1986: Tanabe Campus (present Kyotanabe Campus) was opened.
1986: The Tanabe Campus (the present-day Kyotanabe Campus) was opened.
1986: The Tanabe Campus (the present-day Kyotanabe Campus) was opened.

sen.j: 1986年 - 同志社女子大学短期大学部（英米語科・日本語日本文学科）を設立。
sen.e: 1986: Doshisha Women's Junior College (Departments of English and American Language, Japanese Language, and Literature) was founded.
1986: Doshisha Women's Junior College (including the departments of English and American Language, Japanese Language, and Literature) was founded.
1986: Doshisha Women's Junior College (including the departments of English and American Language, Japanese Language, and Literature) was founded.

sen.j: 1989年 - 学芸学部日本語日本文学科開設。
sen.e: 1989: Faculty of Liberal Arts Department of Japanese Language and Literature was founded.
1989: The Faculty of the Liberal Arts Department of Japanese Language and Literature was founded.
1989: The Faculty of the Liberal Arts Department of Japanese Language and Literature was founded.

sen.j: 2000年 - 現代社会学部社会システム学科開設。
sen.e: 2000: Faculty of Contemporary Social Studies Department of Social System Studies was founded.
2000: The Faculty of the Contemporary Social Studies Department of Social System Studies was founded.
2000: The Faculty of the Contemporary Social Studies Department of Social System Studies was founded.

sen.j: 2002年 - 学芸学部情報メディア学科開設。
sen.e: 2002: Faculty of Liberal Arts Department of Information and Media was founded.
2002: The Faculty of Liberal Arts Department of Information and Media was founded.

sen.j: 2003年 - 短期大学部を廃止。
sen.e: 2003: Doshisha Women's Junior College was abolished.

sen.j: 徽章
徽章は、同志社の徽章である正三角形を3つ寄せたものの下に、「D W C L A」（「Doshisha Womens College of Liberal Arts」の略）の文字を入れたマークである。
sen.e: The emblem of Doshisha Women's College of Liberal Arts has three triangles, which are also used for an emblem of the Doshisha, and under these triangles there are letters of "D W C L A" (which stands for Doshisha Women's College of Liberal Arts).

The emblem of Doshisha Women's College of Liberal Arts has three triangles, which are also featured in the emblem of the Doshisha, and under these triangles there are the letters "DWCLA" (which together stand for Doshisha Women's College of Liberal Arts).

The emblem of Doshisha Women's College of Liberal Arts has three triangles, which are also featured in the emblem of the Doshisha, and under these triangles there are the letters "DWCLA" (which together stand for Doshisha Women's College of Liberal Arts).

sen.j: 大学祭は同志社大学と同様に、同志社英学校の創立記念日である11月29日を前に3日間の前夜祭「同志社EVE」が今出川キャンパスで開かれる。
sen.e: Just like Doshisha University, Doshisha Women's College of Liberal Arts holds "Doshisha Eve" on the Imadegawa Campus every year for 3 days before November 29, which is the anniversary of the founding of Doshisha English School.

Like Doshisha University, Doshisha Women's College of Liberal Arts holds "Doshisha Eve" on the Imadegawa Campus every year for three days prior to November 29, which is the anniversary of the founding of the Doshisha English School.

Like Doshisha University, Doshisha Women's College of Liberal Arts holds "Doshisha Eve" on the Imadegawa Campus every year for three days prior to November 29, which is the anniversary of the founding of the Doshisha English School.

sen.j: かつては同志社全学校でEVEを開催してきたが、1950年代頃より独自のEVEを開催するようになり、1962年から正式の大学祭として位置づけられるようになった。
sen.e: The whole Doshisha schools once held the "Doshisha Eve" together, but each school came to hold its own festival since 1950s, and "Doshisha Eve" at Doshisha Women's College of Liberal Arts was officially approved as a university festival since 1962.

All the Doshisha schools once celebrated "Doshisha Eve" together, but since the 1950s each school has come to hold its own festival, and in 1962 "Doshisha Eve" at Doshisha Women's College of Liberal Arts was officially approved as a university festival.

sen.j: 同志社女子大学には、卒業生全員が加入している同志社女子大学同窓会「Vine（ヴァイン）の会」がある。
sen.e: Doshisha Women's College of Liberal Arts has an alumni association called "Vine", in which all graduates are included.
Doshisha Women's College of Liberal Arts has an alumni association called "Vine," in which all graduates are included.
Doshisha Women's College of Liberal Arts has an alumni association called "Vine," in which all graduates are included.

sen.j: Vineとは、英語で「蔓」や「葡萄の蔓」を意味し、大学と卒業生を結ぶ「蔓」となることを希望して名付けられた。
sen.e: Vine means a "climbing plant" or "grapevine" in English, and the alumni association was named after it in the hope of connecting the university and the graduates.
The word "vine" means a "climbing plant" or "grapevine" in English, and the alumni association was named after it in the hope of fostering a connection between the university and its graduates.

James-Kan, designed by Goichi TAKEDA, was completed in 1914.

sen.j: 京田辺市との協定
京田辺市の地学連携事業の一環として、同志社大学や同志社国際中学校・高等学校とともに広範な分野での連携を目的とした協定。
sen.e: As one of the regional collaboration programs, Kyotanabe City made an agreement with Doshisha Women's College of Liberal Arts, Doshisha University, and Doshisha International Junior and Senior High School to collaborate in a wide area.
sen.cmt: 原文には「同志社女子大学」という言葉がありませんが、内容的には含まれているので訳文には入れてあります。
sen.e: As one of the regional collaboration programs, Kyotanabe City established an agreement with Doshisha Women's College of Liberal Arts, Doshisha University, and Doshisha International Junior and Senior High School to work together in a wide range of activities.
